content.body: Justin Ridgewell: Args being implicitly public works reasonably well in Python, imxp. (And you can now dictate that some args are positional-only and not available by name.) Or is the concern just that exposing arg name of *existing* functions, predating such a syntax, would be a problem?
content.formatted_body: Justin Ridgewell: Args being implicitly public works reasonably well in Python, imxp. (And you can now dictate that some args are positional-only and not available by name.) Or is the concern just that exposing arg name of existing functions, predating such a syntax, would be a problem?

content.body: My worry would be libraries who are unaware, but users who are.
JS devs don’t currently need to think about it, and so it’s normal for it to change without updating the major.
Additionally, what if the lib went through a minifier? What are the public names now?
And what will they be the next time it’s run though?
Terser uses char frequency to select mangled names. A completely unrelated code change in a string can cause the mangled name in a function to change.
I think if JS did add actual named parameters, you would have to opt-in somehow.

content.body: I spent hours thinking over why something was hard for me to understand and expressed it as clearly and concisely as I am capable.
in that sense it is subjective, but I feel like if I claimed "the sky is blue" at this point someone would "nuh uh" me
Which part do you think is being dismissed?
In a sense, I read your comment as a difficulty in translating the code into an English phrase.
And my thought to answer is "well this is how I would say it"
I didn't feel dismissed at all by your comment
I did want to clarify the notion of subject at that point but now it's just a chain of disagreeing with every presupposition I had
I didn't expect to convince anyone per se but I certainly hoped to clearly express where I was coming from
at this point I don't feel like I can speak again until somebody acknowledges what I was actually trying to say
and it's frustrating because I would expect that from the broader community, that's why I shy away from these threads so often, but
anyway I don't think it's a good place for round-and-round conversations

Rereading:
> It's worth noting here that mathematical function notation sometimes uses a subscript for a similar purpose: e.g. logb(x). We bind b first, and indeed, could pass logb as a function instead of feeding it an x right away.
content.formatted_body:
Rereading:

It's worth noting here that mathematical function notation sometimes uses a subscript for a similar purpose: e.g. logb(x). We bind b first, and indeed, could pass logb as a function instead of feeding it an x right away.

content.body: otherwise one person spends hours trying to dot every i and cross every t while others spend two minutes regurgitating some entrenched view
If I understand right, you're treating `log` as something that would need to a bound to a context `b`?
content.formatted_body: If I understand right, you're treating log as something that would need to a bound to a context b?

content.body: Which would always be on the RHS of the `log` expression
